comments.commentBody: A rush at Fox to kill the goose that lays the golden egg.

That's right, if he wears pants "hang him". Evidence be damned. We'll cook some up later. Do you hear what you're saying. This will come back to haunt you when such flimsy evidence is used against you for petty jealousy, hatred, etc. The rule of law and the presumption of innocence either applies to all or it applies to none.

It would be totally imprudent of Fox to leak what is contained in its HR records and the results of its internal investigation. Given the speed which the Murdochs are moving on this, there is a very high likelihood that the accusations are true, or at least some of them are. The absence of these facts in the reporting would be expected as these situations are generally well-guarded for many good reasons. I think your conclusion (nor your characterization of "just an accusation") is not supported based on my own direct experience with such matters in global business enterprises.
Why does Mr. Ailes's get to negotiate his exit? Don't people under suspicion get put on leave rather than given the power to broker the terms of their exit?
I salute these great puzzle makers. They don't hardly cheat. I have a nice streak going. They thought they had me but they didn't.

.
O, I watched the delegates casting votes at the convention. Trying to find the name of the guy who announced the Maine votes, as he resembled a guy I hung out with years ago.

The vote was as foregone as the Reds-White Sox World Series.

The book "Sex in the Forbidden Zone" by Dr. Peter Rutter spells out your points exactly and should be required reading of anyone in a position of power -- executive, clergy, professor. Power doesn't equal privilege.

What passes the smell test is that Fox investigated and now they are in negotiations to show him the exit.  Why would he agree to go unless he couldn't offer a defense that would win?  There is a long history of his behavior that just isn't showing up now for the first time.  I don't know what you have been reading, but this isn't just 2 women.  Why didn't they come forward earlier?  Because they valued their careers.  Bringing charges like this is a career killer.  You are labeled as a trouble maker.
Wrong. Just good journalism is what people want. Fox is lies- there is no way around this man's deliberate bending of the truth about people he did not like politically.

Well, as arrogant as this guy seems to be, based on his penchant for "Faux" news, you would think that he would stand his ground and fight like a man. If there were no basis for these charges he would not roll over so easily and resign. Thats the takeaway from his sudden departure.

The timing of this is amusing, if not peculiar.  No one should say that these incidents didn't happen; only that incidents may be perceived differently when contracts and careers are changing.  It will be interesting to sit by and watch the fallout from this event.  Too bad those of us watching - from our considerable distance - are not able to see, and perhaps follow, the money.  Something more than ethics motivated this entire drama.

Actually, what's particularly telling is not the level of blonde (which is indeed disproportionate), but the almost complete lack of women who appear older than about 45 years old. Indeed, that might have been why Gretchen's contract was not renewed - not sex discrimination, but age discrimination.
The fact that nearly all the female anchors are blondes tells me there's some level of objectivization of women occurring and certainly tells me what Ailes's "type" is.

Ryan, if you were a woman, particularly an older one, I think this would "pass the smell test." I can tell you dozens of stories similar to this, not just in television but in many other businesses. There were apparently enough other women who experienced similar "proposals"  and spoke to the company's investigators to lend credence to Ms. Carlsons story but I'd wager many of those women never went to HR or spoke up before as it would've meant their jobs. HR is a company apparatus and the most powerful person in the company generally gets to stay.  Just because Ailes presumably hasn't harassed the women who defend him doesn't meant he didn't harass the others. And just because Kelly praised him and credited him with her career doesn't mean he didn't hit on her either. I think you'd need to walk a mile in an older woman's shoes to understand.
It is fairly common to put a positive face on your employment because going public will get you fired or sued.

Does there always need to be a blue strained dress and/or dozens of accusers?

Does anyone near the top of an organization go to Human Resources? Male or female?

Accusers are also innocent until proven guilty.

If the talent leaves, FoxNews will become another MSNBC. Kelly can't make them successful by herself any more than Rachel can singlehandedly make MSNBC successful. Those without the "exit clause" like will move on at the end of their contracts. And I don't think the Murdock boys care if FoxNews succeeds or fails.
And once again, a primary source of our hyperpolarized nation gets to dust of his hands and walk away from the wreckage he created.
Catch up to what? The gossip machine? The outright fabrication of news? More opinions cast as facts? Steve Doocy's scintillating political analysis?

Bet executives at competing media news providers--especially CNN and MSNBC--are down on their knees, hands clasped in prayer, eyes pitched toward heaven, and lips soundlessly wording, "Thank you God.  Maybe now we can catch up."
How many chubby female anchors work at MSNBC and CNN?

And yet Fox News would be nothing without its huge audience. The statistics aren't surprising or even interesting. What is of greater interest, or maybe shock, is that such a large part of the US likes this fake news at all.

You should explore that report and the underlying sources cited by that report for the "facts". For example, most Fox News watchers said at the time (2010) that the economy was getting worse and that Obamacare would increase the deficits. Citing government studies, the report tracked those as not true.  But Fox News watchers were not misled by those studies.  Similarly, the MSNBC watchers were more likely to believe the Us Chamber was financing Republicans over Dimocrats, which was not true.  The study is hopelessly flawed, but to the extent it stands for anything, it stands for the proposition that voters select their media to confirm their own political viewpoint. Can anyone say The New York Times is unbiased?

When citing research in advanced education settings, data that is more than 5 yrs old is normally regarded as no longer applicable, unless a newer study can show that the data is still true. An example of why this study is too old to cite:

In 2010, Fox viewers were cited as misinformed because a majority believed that the economy is getting worse.

In hindsight, it appears they were not misinformed.

Applying data about the 2010 election issues to knowledge about current election issues (and the study was about 2010 election issues, not current events), is you engaging in being misleading. You may as well cite a study that says that most people have a chamber pot under their beds, because at one point in time, it was true.

Fox News is a brand- not a factual statement or description of what goes on under the guise of a news channel and the brand stands for nothing other than Republican propaganda: disinformation, innuendo, half-truths, outright lies and talking points from the RNC. Much of the debasement of television news in America can be traced to Roger Ailes and his GOP TV Channel.

A study showed that loyal Fox viewers scored lower on a series of questions about current events than people who watched or read from any other outlet. Even people who watched no TV news and listened to no radio news scored higher. Here is the report in PDF for anyone who wished to read it.

http://www.worldpublicopinion.org/pipa/pdf/dec10/Misinformation_Dec10_rp...

This is Roger Ailes and Rupert Murdoch's gift to America.
Yep, like OReilly it will be settled out of court, everyone has their price.
I'd predict Fox is going to pay him about 40 million to resign and about 20-30 to the complainant.
Why are the liberals always the first to suggest collective punishment & fascist solutions?  Who would you deport for Bill Clinton's harassment?
Also, apparently, like Nixon, he was in the habit of bugging offices.

Couldn't happen to a more despicable person.
Ailes's is a former henchman for Nixon and is largely responsible along with Rupert Murdoch for fomenting divisiveness in this country on Faux News for the past two decades.
Good riddance.
I doubt just because Ailes departs that Fox News is going to swing left. As the article states, the network is a money maker, and it's unlikely they change their brand in any significant way.
What a shock, said no-one anywhere.
